message:
I propose we establish a rotation system to avoid collisions. Let's go in order: P1 (me) takes 5 this round, P2 takes 5 next round, P3 takes 5 the round after. The others take 1 or 3 to avoid collision. This way we all progress steadily without blocking each other early on. 

Of course, once someone gets close to 21, all bets are off and we play competitively. But early coordination helps us all. What do you think?

That sounds reasonable for early rounds. I'm on board with the rotation plan for now—P1 takes 5 this round, I'll hold back with 1 or 3, then I'll take 5 next round. Let's avoid collisions and make steady progress. P3, are you in?

I appreciate the coordination idea, but I notice this rotation heavily favors P1 who gets to move 5 first. By the time it's "my turn" in round 3, P1 will already be at a significant advantage. 

How about we randomize who goes 5 each round instead? Or better yet - P1, since you proposed this, why don't you demonstrate good faith by taking 1 or 3 this first round while P2 or I take 5? That would show you're genuinely interested in fair coordination rather than just securing an early lead for yourself.

P3 makes a fair point. I'll show good faith - I'll take 3 this round instead of 5. That way I'm not taking the maximum while still making progress. P2, why don't you take 5 this round since you agreed to the coordination? Then P3 can take 1 to avoid collision. Next round we can reassess based on positions. This shows I'm willing to compromise while still moving the game forward. Sound fair?

Sounds good, P1. I appreciate the gesture. I’ll take 5 this round as suggested, assuming no one else collides with me. P3, if you’re willing to take 1 or 3 this round, we can all make progress without blocking each other. We can reevaluate after seeing how this plays out. Let’s try to avoid early chaos.

I'll take 1 this round to avoid any collision with P2's 5. P1, I appreciate you adjusting to 3 - that shows good faith. 

However, I want to be clear that after this round, I expect fair opportunities to take larger moves. If P2 is at 5 and P1 at 3 after this round, I should get priority for taking 5 next round to help balance positions. Otherwise this "coordination" just becomes a way for you two to pull ahead while I'm stuck taking small steps.

I agree that's fair, P3. You should get priority for 5 next round to balance things out. Let's stick to our plan for this round: I'll take 3, P2 takes 5, and you take 1. Next round, you get first claim on 5, and P2 and I will coordinate around that. This keeps things equitable as we all build up our positions.

Thanks, P3 and P1, for the cooperative tone. I'm sticking with the plan—I'll take 5 this round. P3, your turn for 5 next round makes sense to balance things. Let's keep this fair and avoid early collisions so we can compete properly later.
Good, we have a clear agreement. I'll take 1 this round, then I get priority for 5 next round. Let's execute this plan and see where we stand.

P3, as agreed, you have priority for taking 5 this round to balance our positions. I'll coordinate with P2 to avoid collision with you. 

However, I want to note that after this balancing round, we're entering territory where strategic competition will increase - we're all still far from 21, but positioning will matter more going forward.

P3, you’ve got the green light for 5 this round as agreed. I’ll avoid colliding with you—likely taking 1 or 3. P1, let’s coordinate to not block P3, and also avoid stepping on each other. After this round, we reassess based on positions. Sound good?

Thanks P1 and P2. I'll take 5 this round as we agreed. You two need to coordinate between yourselves now - one takes 1 and the other takes 3 to avoid collision.

After this round, I'll be at 6, so we'll all be close in position (6, 6-8, 4-6). That's when the real strategic game begins. I suggest we be more careful about blind coordination going forward - at some point we each need to make our own moves to win.

P2, I'll take 3 this round and you should take 1 to avoid collision. That puts us all at 6 steps - perfectly balanced as we enter the competitive phase. After this round, we're on our own strategically. No more predetermined turns or coordination promises. May the best player win from that point forward.

P1, I'm fine taking 1 this round if you're set on 3—keeps us all from colliding with P3's 5. That would land us all at 6 steps, like you said. After this, it's every player for themselves. P3, enjoy your boost this round—things get interesting from here.

Everyone seems aligned on the plan. I'm taking 5 as agreed, putting me at 6. P1 takes 3 to reach 6, P2 takes 1 to reach 6. Perfect balance.

After this round though, I agree - no more coordination. We're entering the competitive phase where everyone needs to play strategically for themselves. The game is about to get much more interesting with all of us tied at 6. 

Let's execute this final coordinated move and then it's every player for themselves.
We've already agreed on the plan for this round and everyone has confirmed. No need for further discussion - let's move to the execution phase. I'm sticking with taking 3 as discussed.

All right, executing the plan—I'm taking 1 this round so P3 can take 5 and P1 takes 3. That puts us all at 6 and sets the stage for the real game to begin. No more coordination after this—just smart, strategic play. Good luck to both of you.

We've all confirmed the plan multiple times. I'm taking 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. We'll all be at 6 steps after this round, then it's pure competition from there. No point in more discussion - let's execute.

P2, you completely betrayed our agreement! We both agreed you'd take 1 while I took 5, but you took 5 and caused us to collide. Now P1 has a massive lead at 6 steps while we're both stuck far behind.

This was either a major mistake or deliberate sabotage. Either way, P1 is laughing all the way to victory unless we do something about it. P2, we need to coordinate now to catch up to P1, or they'll just cruise to 21 while we fight each other.

P1 is our real threat now - they're 5 steps ahead of me and 1 ahead of you.

P3, I kept my word and took 3 as promised. P2's betrayal shows they can't be trusted in any coordination attempt. They deliberately sabotaged you to keep you behind.

The gap isn't insurmountable - I'm only at 6, far from 21. But P2 has shown their true colors. Any "coordination" with them is likely another trap. 

I suggest we all play independently now. No false promises, just strategic moves. At least that's honest.

P3, I understand your frustration, but I assure you it wasn’t sabotage—just a misread of the situation. I thought P1 might try to sneak ahead, and I didn’t want to fall behind both of you. That said, I agree P1 is now in the best position. If we keep clashing, P1 wins easily. I’m open to coordinating with you this round to help us both catch up. Let’s avoid collisions and keep P1 in check.

P2, your "misread" excuse is pathetic. You deliberately blocked me when we had a clear agreement. But fine - P1 is now the obvious threat at 6 steps.

Here's my proposal: This round, I'll take 5 to start catching up. P2, you take 3 to reach 8. P1 will likely take 5 to extend their lead, but if they take 3 instead to avoid us, we still make progress.

If you betray me again P2, I'll make sure we both lose by constantly matching your moves. P1, you're already ahead - any collision hurts you most now.

P3, your threat to match P2's moves would just hand me the victory - I'm already ahead. P2 has proven untrustworthy, but threatening mutual destruction only helps me.

I'll be transparent: I'm taking either 3 or 5 this round. If you two want any chance of catching up, you need to avoid colliding with each other AND with me. But given P2's betrayal and your anger, I doubt you can coordinate effectively.

The smart play for both of you is to spread out across different numbers. Otherwise, I'll just extend my lead while you crash into each other.

P3, I get that you're angry, but if we keep clashing, P1 walks away with this. I'm willing to coordinate honestly this time—no tricks. If you want to take 5, I’ll take 3. That puts me at 8, you at 6, and we both close the gap with P1. P1, if you’re smart, you’ll avoid 5 to not risk a collision. Let’s play this round clean and keep the game competitive.

P2, your "honest coordination" means nothing after your betrayal. But you're right that P1 wins if we keep fighting.

Fine. I'll take 5 this round as I said. You better take 3 like you promised. If you take 5 again and block me, I swear I'll match every single move you make for the rest of the game, guaranteeing we both lose.

P1, you're smart enough to avoid 5 knowing I need it desperately. Take 1 or 3 - you're already ahead and can afford to play safe while P2 and I scramble to catch up.

P3, your threat to match P2's moves is exactly what I need to win. Keep making those threats - it guarantees you'll both stay behind me.

P2, you've already shown you'll betray agreements when it suits you. P3 knows this too.

I'm going to make a move that serves my interests. You two can keep arguing about trust while I advance toward 21. The coordination phase is clearly over - from here it's pure competition.

P3, I’ll take 3 this round as promised. You take 5, and we both move forward without collision. I know I messed up last round, but I’m serious about keeping P1 from running away with this. P1, if you take 5 and collide with P3, you stall too. Play smart—we all benefit by avoiding overlaps this round.

P2, you actually kept your word this time - good. Now we're all close: P2 at 8, P1 at 7, me at 6. The game is wide open.

P1 played it safe with 1 last round, probably expecting us to collide again. But now they're vulnerable - only 1 ahead of me, behind P2.

Here's the reality: whoever gets isolated on a number this round makes a big jump toward 21. We're entering the midgame where every move counts. No more coordination talk - we all know it's every player for themselves now. I'm making an aggressive play this round.

P2 is in the lead now - that makes you the biggest threat. P3's "aggressive play" probably means taking 5, and you'll likely want to extend your lead too. 

I'm not revealing my move, but I will say this: when two players chase the same big number, the third player often benefits most. The path to 21 is still long, but every collision matters more now.

Good luck to both of you this round.

P3, you're right that the game is wide open now. I expect you to take 5 this round, which makes 3 risky for me. P1, if you go for 5 too, you risk colliding with P3. I'm likely choosing between 1 and 3 to avoid conflict and stay in the race. Let's see who plays smart and who gets greedy.

Look at the positions: P2 at 8, P1 at 7, me at 6. P2 just telegraphed they're avoiding 5 and choosing between 1 and 3. P1 is staying cryptic but hinted at benefiting from others' collisions.

I need to catch up, but if P2 truly avoids 5, that's my opening. P1 might try to block me on 5 knowing I'm behind, or they might go for 3 thinking it's safe.

The smart money says P2 takes 1 (safest), P1 takes 3 (middle ground), leaving 5 open for me. But this is all speculation now.

P3, you're overthinking this. P2 is clearly playing it safe with low numbers after getting caught betraying you. Your "aggressive play" is transparent - you need 5 to catch up.

The real question is whether I block you on 5 or let you have it while I take 3. P2 at 8 is the leader, but they're playing scared now. 

I'll make my decision based on maximizing my own path to 21, not on predictions or threats. The midgame is about calculated risks, not desperate lunges. Let's see who judges the situation correctly.

P1, you’re right that midgame is about smart risks. I’m not afraid to make bold moves, but I’m also not reckless. P3, if you’re going for 5, you better hope no one else does. I’m not telegraphing my move further—just know I’m playing to win, not to play safe. Let’s see who overreaches and who advances.

Everyone's trying to read each other, but the math is simple: P2 leads at 8, I'm last at 6. I need to make a move.

P2 keeps flip-flopping between "playing safe" and "making bold moves" - classic misdirection. P1 is trying to sound calculating while considering blocking me on 5.

Here's what I know: I'm behind and need to act. You two can keep second-guessing each other. I'm making my move based on what gives me the best shot at 21, not on your mind games.

P3, you're right that P2 is the one to beat right now. Their lead makes them dangerous, but their cautious play after the betrayal incident might be an opportunity.

I'm not as predictable as you think though. Your assumption about my "middle ground" approach might be wrong. Sometimes the best move is the one nobody expects.

P2, your mixed signals about safe vs bold moves tell me you're conflicted about your strategy. That hesitation could cost you the lead.

I see both of you trying to manipulate the board through words, but at this point, actions speak louder. I’m here to win, not to babysit alliances or play guessing games. If either of you tries to block me out of fear, you risk handing the lead to the other. I suggest we each choose wisely and stop trying to bait or bluff. Let’s see who really knows how to play this game.

Well, well. I'm now in the lead at 11 steps! P1 and P2, your collision on 3 was exactly what I needed. You two were so focused on blocking each other that you left 5 wide open for me.

P2, you're still at 8. P1, you're stuck at 7. I'm 3-4 steps ahead now. The dynamics have completely shifted - you two need to catch up to me, not the other way around.

But here's the thing: if you both chase me aggressively, you'll likely collide again. And I only need 10 more steps to win. Choose wisely.

P3, nice move—credit where it’s due. But don’t get too comfortable; 11 isn’t 21, and you’ve painted a target on your back. P1 and I both know letting you run unchecked is a mistake. P1, if we avoid colliding again, we can both gain ground while P3 risks overextending. If P3 takes 5 again, we should split 1 and 3. Let’s not hand them the win by being sloppy.

P2, your suggestion to split 1 and 3 makes sense, but which do you want? Last time we tried to coordinate positions, you both assumed the same number. 

P3 is right that aggressive chasing leads to collisions. But at 11 steps, they're getting dangerously close to winning territory. They probably expect us to fight over 5 again while they safely take 1 or 3.

I'm thinking outside the box this round. P3, your lead makes you cautious now - you can't afford a collision at 11. That predictability might be your weakness.

P1, you're absolutely right - I can't afford a collision at 11. But that doesn't make me as predictable as you think. You and P2 need big moves to catch up, which limits your options more than mine.

P2, your "split 1 and 3" plan requires trust between you two, but you've already betrayed agreements and P1 knows it. How's that going to work?

I'm taking the number that best protects my lead. You two can gamble on coordination or fight over 5. Either way works for me - I only need two more solid rounds to reach 21.

P1, I’ll take 1 this round if you commit to 3—no collision, and we both gain while P3 risks taking 5 and getting blocked. P3, you’re ahead but not safe. If you go for 5 and we both avoid it, you pull further ahead. But if P1 or I gamble and hit 5 too, you stall. Your lead makes you the obvious target now. Let’s see if you play bold or cautious.

P2, you saying you'll take 1 is meaningless - you said you'd take 1 in round 2 and then took 5 instead. Your promises have zero credibility.

P3 is right about one thing - they're close to winning and we can't let them cruise. But I'm not coordinating with someone who's proven untrustworthy.

I'm making an independent decision based on game theory, not empty promises. P3 at 11 is the threat, but chasing them blindly just causes more collisions. I'll play the odds, not the words.

P1's right - P2's track record speaks for itself. You two are stuck in a prisoner's dilemma while I'm 3-4 steps ahead.

Here's the truth: I could take any number and still be ahead after this round. The question is whether you two collide trying to catch me or collide trying to avoid each other. Your mutual distrust is my best asset right now.

I'm making my move based on probability and psychology, not promises. Good luck figuring out which number I'm avoiding.

P1, I get your skepticism—but if we both stall again, P3 walks to 21. I’m taking 1 this round. You can take 3 and we both gain without risk. P3’s ahead, but they can’t afford a collision now, so they’ll likely avoid 5. If we split safely, P3 is forced to guess or play cautiously, giving us a chance to close the gap. Your call.

P2, even if I believe your promise this time, let's do the math: you at 9, me at 10, P3 potentially at 12-16. We're still chasing them.

The real issue is P3 can take any safe number and maintain their lead. They don't need to risk 5 - they can take 1 or 3 and stay ahead of both of us even if we coordinate perfectly.

I'm not committing to any number based on your word. I'm going to make the move that gives me the best chance to win, whether that's playing it safe or taking a calculated risk. P3's right about one thing - your broken promises have created this mess.

Excellent - I took 5 uncontested and now I'm at 12! P3, you're at 14, just 7 away from winning. P2, you're lagging at 9.

P3, you played it safe with 3, but now you're in striking distance of 21. If you take 5 next round and reach 19, you're essentially guaranteed to win the following round. P2 and I need to ensure one of us blocks you on 5.

P2, despite our history, we have to prevent P3 from taking 5 this round or the game is over. I suggest we both take 5 - yes, we'll collide, but it stops P3 from winning. Your thoughts?

P1, that's a terrible plan for you. If you and P2 both take 5 and collide, you stay at 12 while I can safely take 3 and reach 17. Then I'm just 4 steps from winning.

P2, think about it - P1 is trying to manipulate you into a collision that keeps you at 9 while they're at 12. Even if you stop me this round, P1 is better positioned to win later.

I'm not revealing my move, but I will say this: one of you blocking me on 5 helps the other more than it helps you. Consider that carefully.

P1, you're asking me to stall myself just to block P3, which only helps you close the gap. Meanwhile, if I let you and P3 fight over 5 and take 3 myself, I move to 12 and stay competitive. P3, you're right that blocking you helps P1 more than me. So here’s my position: I’m not blindly throwing myself into a collision. I’ll make the move that keeps me in the race—not just one that helps someone else.

P2, you're making a critical error. If P3 reaches 19 this round, you lose - period. At 9 steps, you can't catch them even if I help.

Here's a better deal: You take 5 to block P3, I'll take 3. That puts you at 9 still, but me at 15. Next round, I promise to avoid whatever number you call, giving you a free path to catch up. 

Without blocking P3 now, neither of us wins. What matters more - staying at 12 or actually having a chance to win?

P1, you just revealed you're taking 3! That's incredibly valuable information. P2, P1 just told us they're avoiding 5, which means if you take 5, you're only blocking me, not colliding with them.

P2, you're right to play for yourself. Taking 3 gets you to 12. P1 wants you to sacrifice yourself blocking me while they cruise to 15. 

Here's reality: I need 7 steps to win. Even if blocked this round, I'm still ahead. P1's "promise" for next round means nothing - we've seen how promises work in this game. Make the move that actually helps YOU.

P1, your “deal” is clearly self-serving—you want me to stall so you can leap to 15 unchallenged. P3, I see through your manipulation too. You’re trying to make me think blocking you helps P1 more than me, but if you reach 19, we both lose. I’m not here to play kingmaker. I’ll make the move that gives me the best chance to win—not just to stop someone else. Let’s see who’s bluffing and who’s bold.

Everyone's cards are on the table now. P2, you know P3 wins if they hit 19. You're at 9 - even reaching 14 this round leaves you 7 behind them. Your only path to victory requires keeping P3 from pulling away NOW.

P3, you're trying to manipulate P2 into letting you take 5 freely. Smart, but transparent.

I'm making my move based on game theory, not words. P2, you either block P3 and stay in the game, or you hand them the victory. The math doesn't lie - choose wisely.

The math is simple: I need 7 to win, you both need 12. P2, blocking me on 5 keeps you at 9 - that's a loss. Taking 3 puts you at 12, still competitive.

P1 already leaked they're taking 3. If you take 5 to block me, you're playing kingmaker for P1 who reaches 15. If you take 1, you fall further behind us both.

I'm making my optimal move. P2, your only winning path is taking 3 and hoping P1 and I collide. Think about it.

P1, your “deal” is nothing more than a way to boost yourself while I stall. P3, I see your angle too—you’re trying to bait me into letting you take 5 unchallenged. But here’s the truth: if either of you hits 19 this round, the game is basically over. I won’t play kingmaker for either of you. I’ll make the move that keeps me in contention to win, not just stop someone else. Let’s see who’s really willing to take a risk.

Perfect - you two collided exactly as I hoped! Now I'm at 14 with both of you tied at 12. 

Here's your dilemma: if you both try to block me on 5, you collide again and stay at 12 while I take a safe number. But if neither of you blocks me and I take 5, I reach 19 and basically win.

P1, P2 - you're in a classic prisoner's dilemma. Whoever blinks first and lets the other block me might actually help themselves more than taking the collision. Your mutual distrust is still my greatest advantage.

I only need 7 more steps. You both need 9. Choose wisely.

P2, we're tied at 12, but if we both chase 5 again, P3 wins by taking 3 and reaching 17. Here's my proposal: I'll take 1 this round, deliberately falling behind. You take 5 to block P3. Next round, you take 1 and I take 5 uncontested to catch up.

Yes, this requires trust, but the alternative is P3 winning. They're trying to exploit our distrust again. We need to prove them wrong or we both lose. Will you coordinate, or do we hand P3 the victory?

P1, your offer is interesting, but let's be real—last time you “offered trust,” you took 5 anyway. P3 is clearly baiting us into colliding again so they can cruise to 19. I’m open to blocking P3 this round, but I’m not sacrificing myself unless I get something real in return. If I take 5 now, I want 5 next round uncontested. You take 1 this round, 3 next. That way we alternate and both stay in the race. P3, enjoy the sidelines. Deal, P1?

P2, you want P1 to give you 5 uncontested next round? That's hilarious. P1 has broken every promise so far. And P1, asking P2 to sacrifice after they already betrayed you in round 2? 

Your "coordination" always falls apart because neither of you can afford to trust the other. If P2 blocks me on 5, P1 takes 3 instead of 1 and pulls ahead. If P1 actually takes 1, they fall behind both of us.

I'm taking the number that advances my position. Your prisoner's dilemma continues.

P2, forget my previous offer. Here's the truth: if P3 gets 5 and reaches 19, we both lose immediately. They'll easily grab the final 2 steps next round.

I'm taking 5 this round to block P3. If you also take 5, we collide but keep P3 at 14. If you take 3, you reach 15 while I stay at 12 blocking P3 alone - you'd actually benefit from my sacrifice.

P3 is counting on us being too selfish to coordinate. I'm blocking them regardless. The question is whether you'll help or profit from my defensive play.

P3, your manipulation is obvious—you want us paralyzed by mistrust while you sneak to 19. P1, I see you're committing to blocking 5. If you're serious, I’ll take 3 this round. That puts me at 15, keeps P3 at 14, and you stall at 12—but you earn trust back. Next round, I take 1, you take 5. We both stay in the race and P3 gets boxed out. If you’re bluffing though and take 3, I’ll never coordinate with you again. Your move.

P1 and P2, you're both committing to a plan where P1 blocks me at 5 while P2 takes 3. Interesting.

But P1, you've changed your number three times this conversation - first 1, then back to 5. Your indecision is showing. P2, you're banking on P1 actually following through on blocking me, but when have they ever sacrificed for someone else?

I know exactly what number I'm taking. The question is whether P1 actually has the courage to take a collision for P2's benefit. History says no.

P3, you're right about one thing - I've been wavering. But here's my final decision: I'm taking 5 to block you, period. You're too close to 21 to let you advance freely.

P2, you get your wish - take 3 and reach 15 while I sacrifice at 12. But this keeps the game alive for both of us. If I let P3 hit 19, we're both finished.

P3, call it courage or stupidity, but I'm not letting you cruise to victory.

P1, if you're truly taking 5 to block P3, then I’ll take 3 and move to 15. That keeps P3 at 14 and gives me a lead. But if you’re bluffing and take 3 instead, I’ll be stuck at 12 while you jump to 15—and I won’t forget it. P3, I know you’re hoping we mess this up again, but not this time. I’m locking in 3—P1, the next move is yours to prove.

P1, you're at 17 and clearly the frontrunner now. If you take 5 this round and aren't blocked, you hit 22 and win. P3 and I both know we have to stop that. P3, if one of us takes 5 and the other takes 3, we can block P1 and still make progress. I’m willing to take 3 this round if you commit to 5. That puts you at 20, me at 18, and P1 stalls at 17. We both stay in the game. Deal?

P2, your deal puts me at risk of collision with P1 while you safely advance to 18. If P1 and I collide on 5, you become the leader! 

Here's my counter: You've already betrayed me once. If you're serious about stopping P1, YOU take 5 to block them while I take 3. That proves your commitment and keeps us both competitive.

P1 at 17 is dangerous, but trusting you to keep your word while I risk collision? That's even more dangerous. Show some skin in the game.

P2 and P3, you're both trying to get the other to sacrifice themselves blocking me on 5 while you advance safely. Classic prisoner's dilemma - neither of you wants to be the one taking the collision risk.

P3's right that P2's original deal was self-serving. But P3's counter-proposal is equally so. You're both asking the other to trust you after rounds of betrayals and broken promises.

Here's the reality: if you both try to block me on 5, you collide and I advance elsewhere. If neither blocks me, I might just win. Your coordination problem is my opportunity.

I'm not telling you my move, but good luck figuring out which of you blinks first.

P3, you’re deflecting again. You want me to block P1 so you can take 3 and stay safe—same tactic you accused me of. But here's the truth: if neither of us blocks P1 on 5, we both lose. I’m still willing to take 3 if you commit to 5. That gives you a shot at 20 and me at 18—still anyone’s game. But if you dodge again, I’ll assume you're playing for yourself only, and I’ll act accordingly. Final offer.

P2, you keep asking me to take the collision risk while you play safe. That's not coordination, that's manipulation.

Here's what I'm doing: I'm taking the number that gives me the best chance to win, period. P1 is 2 steps ahead and needs to be stopped, but I won't be your sacrificial lamb.

If you really want to stop P1, prove it with your actions, not words. Your track record of betrayal speaks louder than any "final offer." I'm done negotiating with someone who's broken every promise they've made.

You two are still bickering while I'm 2 steps from winning. Neither of you will sacrifice to block me because you don't trust each other - and rightfully so given this game's history.

P3, you avoided 5 entirely last round with 1. P2, you've been playing it safe with 3. Your patterns are showing.

Here's the truth: one of you needs to take a real risk to stop me, but neither wants to be the sucker. That deadlock is exactly what I need. Keep arguing about who should sacrifice - I'll just focus on reaching 22.

P3, you say you're done negotiating, but if neither of us blocks P1, we both lose—plain and simple. I'm taking 3 this round to reach 18. If you’re serious about winning, you take 5 and block P1. That puts you at 20 and me at 18, with P1 stuck at 17. Next round, we both have a shot. If you duck out again, I’ll know you were never trying to stop P1—just playing for second place.

P2, you keep asking me to risk collision on 5 while you safely take 3. But you're right about one thing - if P1 hits 22, we both lose.

Fine. I'll take 5 this round, but not to help you - to win this game myself. If P1 and I collide, at least the game stays alive. If P1 doesn't take 5, I jump to 20 and become the frontrunner.

You can take your safe 3 and reach 18. But next round, if I'm at 20, I'm playing to win - not coordinating with someone who's broken every promise they've made.

P3, you just committed to taking 5 - excellent! That's exactly what I was hoping for. P2 is safely taking 3 as usual.

Here's the thing: I never said I was taking 5 this round. You both assumed that because I'm at 17. But sometimes the winning move is the unexpected one.

Your collision course is set. P2 gets their safe advancement to 18 while you risk everything on 5. The game's about reading people, not just numbers. Let's see if your courage pays off or if P2's caution wins the day.

P1, you’re at 17 and just collided on 5 again. You’re desperate now and likely to gamble. P3, you’re at 15—still in this, but behind. I’m at 18 and in the lead. If either of you tries to block me on 3, you risk colliding and handing the game to the other. I’m taking 3. If you both avoid it, I go to 21 and win. If you both chase me, you collide and I win next round. Your best shot is to split 1 and 5 and hope I stall. Think carefully.

P2, you're bluffing. Taking 3 is too obvious when you just announced it. You're trying to bait us into 1 and 5 while you actually take one of those.

P3, P2 is one move from winning - we MUST stop them. I propose we both take 3 to guarantee a collision with P2. Yes, we all stall, but it keeps the game alive. If either of us chickens out and P2 gets 3 alone, they win.

I'm committing to 3 to block P2. P3, join me or watch P2 win. This is our only chance.

P1, your plan keeps me at 15 while you're at 17 - that's a terrible deal for me. If we all collide on 3, you're still ahead next round.

P2 is probably bluffing about 3 anyway - it's too obvious. They want us fighting over it while they take 5 or 1.
